posts.com:
David Foster Wallace once wrote a piece about David Lynch. In the piece, he coined a new term: "Lynchian". Wallace described a Lynchian tone as "the unbelievably grotesque existing in a kind of union with the unbelievably banal."

He described a husband beating his 1950s housewife to death because she bought the wrong brand of peanut butter. "I told you to buy the JIF," he'd say as he's clobbering her to death. This, he said, would qualify as almost perfectly Lynchian.

I think "I Am Jazz" enters into Lynchian territory. The .webm above shows a simple domestic scene. The women look like average suburban moms. They're relaxing on the couch. One imagines they might be discussing casserole recipes when we cut to them. But it slowly dawns on us that in the living room, with placid expressions on their faces, they're talking about the woman's transvestite son's genitals.

Despite the obvious subtext and the producers' hope to normalize this horror, the average person is totally disgusted. Nevertheless, the viewer is fascinated. We're drawn further into this. The sheer naked horror of what they're saying, the blasé quality with which they're saying it, it creates this brutal paradox that almost rapes the viewer's basic sense of what is decent.

This is yet another scene that one could classify as very archetypally lynchian.

We are presented with a fairly normal scene of a young girl at the doctor with her parents. One may conclude that this is a school checkup or some such thing. It is only when the dialog begins that the utter perversion of normalcy comes creeping down.

This doctor is advising the girl to masturbate her penis, not for the sake of pleasure but to stretch out the skin, all for the purpose of cutting it off and turning it into a cheap imitation of a vaginal canal. The mother looks on with enthusiasm, with understanding, with some twisted version of love and the glint in her eyes gives away her glee. Glee for she is finally getting a daughter 17 years after birthing her third son.

The hapless father shifts uncomfortable as he is presented with this conversation about his daughters need to masturbate, the need to tug a penis that will soon be inverted. All while the middling thought in the back of his head "how is this right" chips away at the last shred of his backbone, a constant reminder of how he can never stand up to his wife, how he cannot save his youngest son. This is the look of hope dying before our eyes.

There are many similarities between Pink Floyd's "The Wall" and the story of Jazz Jennings
It starts with a difficult childhood - In Floyd's case, losing his father in the war and having it replaced with a government school system that erases identity
Jazz also suffered as a child, from abuse, from having his identity erased, and from being raised by jewish people.

Piece by piece, brick by brick, the wall is built up. In Floyd's case, a wall to keep people out, eventually transforming into delusions of being a fascist dictator of the fans he despises
In Jazz's case, the bricks of the delusion. In the early seasons, you see the bricks start to build the delusions, delusions that will last as the wall gets stronger and studier, until eventually Jazz reaches her Trial. The Trial was the surgery itself, where reality and delusion come face to face. The wall was smashed, and she was exposed before her peers to reality - this isn't a game, it's not fun, you cut your genital apart and now they exploded

But The Show Must Go On.

posts.sub: Studios can now be sued for misleading trailers
posts.com:
>Ana de Armas appeared in the trailer for the 2019 film Yesterday, but her character did not make the final cut. Jeff Spicer/Getty Images
>A federal judge rejected Universal Studios' motion to dismiss a lawsuit claiming it misled fans.
>Movie fans filed a class action suit in January claiming they were tricked into watching the film.
>They sued Universal because actress Ana de Armas was in the trailer, but didn't appear in the movie.

>Movie fans will be able to sue studios under false advertising laws if they release misleading trailers for forthcoming releases, a federal judge ruled this week.

>The news was first reported by Variety.

>The trailer for Danny Boyle's 2019 feature "Yesterday" may be considered as false advertising because it included actress Ana de Armas, who did not actually appear in the film, according to a court filing on Tuesday.

>A California district court judge, Stephen V. Wilson, is letting a class action suit filed earlier this year proceed after Universal Studios asked for it be dismissed. Universal argued that it would "open the floodgates" to others who felt they had been misled by trailers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178346545
>Judge Wilson rejected Universal's argument and ruled that the trailers were subject to advertising laws: "At its core, a trailer is an advertisement designed to sell a movie by providing consumers with a preview of the movie."

>Two Ana de Armas fans brought the lawsuit against Universal in January after they paid $3.99 to rent the rom-com online to find that the "No Time to Die" actress didn't appear in the film. At least $5m is being claimed on behalf of the fans in the lawsuit.

>The fans, Peter Michael Rosza and Conor Woulfe, argued that they were tricked into watching "Yesterday" after they saw Armas in the trailer. The complaint said Universal was "unable to rely on fame of the actors playing Jack Malik or Ellie to maximize ticket and movie sales and rentals," and therefore "used Ms. De Armas's fame, radiance and brilliance to promote the film by including her scenes in the movie trailers."

>Judge Wilson said that the moviegoers were not given "any value for their rental or purchase", per the filing, and lawyers will meet again for the case in April.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178352940
>a Bridgestone Corporation shill apparently exists
lol
>fundamental design mistakes with the vehicle
The Ford Explorer was never recalled. Its tires were. Objectively and legally there was no compelling design mistake enough to warrant the NHTSA to recall the vehicle. What you are citing is Bridgestone's unsubstantiated legal conjecture in its attempt to defend itself in court. Those arguments were rejected. I'm not going to go further into it because I am confident beyond any measure I know far more about the famous recall than you do.

>That's a bad analogy
It isn't. It's in fact the perfect analogy. Ford chose to put the tires on their vehicles. At some point prior to the recall Ford also became aware there was a worrying statistical trend regarding those tires but chose to do nothing about it. Bridgestone, when it acquired Firestone, was aware of manufacturing practices that it would consider unsafe in its own factories but chose to do nothing about it.

Likewise, regardless of whether the trailer making is outsourced to a contractor, Universal Studios still chose to put their name on it. They endorsed it by allowing it to be released. They bear legal responsibility for what it depicts and what it promises of their product.

He was the one who devised this system in the first place. Prior to the 90s, the monarchy was funded by the old civil list system that had to be renegotiated once every few years. I think Rian Johnson is the worst writer and producer currently in Hollywood.

The films he makes are so weirdly bizarre to me. It's a bunch of american progressive talking points where strawman opposition are proven wrong in a way that's almost satirical because it's so contrived. Instead of being some sort of expectation-ruining experience for people with prejudices, it just comes off as a cringey, unaware ego project where Rian reinforces what he tries to condemn.

This is most apparent in the casting of main protagonist and antagonist in the Glass Onion. The protagonist is a genius, beautiful woman who was taken advantage of and stolen from. The antagonist was a mediocre man who took what wasn't his. There is no chance on earth, in Rian's mind, where the roles of those two characters could be anything but a black woman and white man. So as I'm watching this and trying to understand the characters, I can't help but think about how smug and self congratulatory Rian is during the whole script. How he imagines himself as uplifting minorities and women against some sort of historic oppression, despite being a wealthy, white man who only got where he was and is due to nepotism, himself. How everything is tailored to fit the current status-quo of what is acceptable to condemn in hollywood and how well the general public will receive it while claiming to be disruptive. It's some of the most grandiose virtue signalling I've ever seen.

He should have been cast into the fire after tanking the biggest franchise on earth, but his handlers keep him around for some reason.

>>178323628
Hope you enjoy Anon. Voyager gets a bad rap, but I unironically think it's the series most in line with what Gene actually was trying to create, with how it maintainst the optimism of the future, without skipping past the part of how everyone got to understand eachother and work as equals, by creating a crew where practically the entire main cast is an outsider to some degree other than Janeway, as the only other proper Starfleet officers are Tuvok, the Vulcan, and Harry Kim who's on his first real asignment. The way they all find their place in the crew over time is I think a lot more in line with the spirit of the show Gene talked about in "The Star Trek Dream" which is one of the segments of Inside Star Trek: https://youtu.be/rpHAUcVC9qk?t=3006 (Basically the 50 minute mark, if it doesn't auto jump there for you.)
I feel like letting the characters actually be outsiders to eachother, and run into issues because of this and learn to work past them is a much more powerful and interesting to watch approach to Star Trek's vision of an inclusive and understanding future, than what too many modern shows, films and even books do, where characters are made in a way that they'd no doubt be seen as outsiders for the way they are by most of society today, but no one in the story actually encounters any issues with them.
Ironically, there is nothing to relate to, in a character who is "like you", but doesn't face any of the struggles you face, and ends up feeling like all the cookie cutter stories about depression where the solution turns out to be "just don't be sad" or "just get help from your pre-existing deeply reliable and trusted friends/family", where for many these aren't straightforward options.

It's got a few really meh episodes (mostly Chakotay ones), but to my mind, the Doctor is the best character in the whole franchise, and almost any episode focusing on him is instant gold.


In place of a TL;DR, instead: Have fun, Anon, and Merry Christmas!

posts.com:
I'm halfway through Season 4 of Voyager. It's better than what I had heard. Not as good as DS9, but I can't remember a single episode that bored me enough to lose interest. Some points I've noted:
- The Kazon are the shittiest hostile race in all of Star Trek and I'm glad they're finally gone from the show. How the fuck are they able to control so much territory when they're basically troglodytes who escaped slavery a mere 50 years ago? All their tech is stolen and they're too stupid to get water of all fucking things, yet they're able to operate and repair ships. How was Culluh even able to keep up with Voyager's speed?
- The Doctor is hands down the best character in the show and perhaps the entire franchise. I also like Neelix a lot, but I feel he's been losing a lot of screentime lately. Seven of Nine seems interesting so far. Chakotay is very boring and one-dimensional, he's little more than Janeway's goody two-shoes yesman. Everyone else is alright.
- Suder should have stayed as a semi-regular character.
- The use of technobabble is way too excessive and annoying here compared to the previous series.
- I'm sure this has been mentioned many times before, but it kinda breaks my suspension of disbelief that Voyager gets repaired so quickly, and always off-screen. They also seem to have an infinite supply of torpedos and shuttles (maybe they can build more with replicated parts?).
- I'm still in disbelief at Harry being the only one left from the "original Voyager". Well, and the baby, I guess.

Ok, so you didnt understand Tarantino's metaphor at all.

The movie follows a simple cycle: either Cliff or Rick go somewhere, and then they go back.
Back and forth, back and forth.
Then there's Margo and Margaret's feet at random intervals, that seemingly have no relation to the story what so ever. And we all know Tarantino loves feet.
And then there's the violence build up. First Cliff and Bruce with only a drop of blood. Then Cliff beating the shit out of that hippy at the ranch. And the final massacre.
And after all of it the movie has a blissful happy ending.

So what's the metaphor?
Tarantino masturbating to his foot fetish.

Back and forth back and forth, first hint of an orgasm comes, but he decides to slow down and continue stroking.
Second orgasm, he's about to cum, but he stops yet again.
And then the climax, the excessive violence, the rivers of blood. Tarantino comes all over our screen.
And the scene where Rick gets to meet his neighbor as the post-nut clarity.

>The fact thatWill Success Spoil Rock Hunter?was Tashlin’s most avant-garde and political film undoubtedly also made it one of his most misunderstood — rivaled, perhaps, only by Chaplin’sA King in New York,also released in 1957 (albeit only in Europe), and paralleling Tashlin’s vision of America in many important aspects (although it goes further in highlighting many of the hysterical 50s excesses, such as the McCarthyite witchhunts, that were systematically left out of Hollywood pictures). Both directors, anticipating Jean-Luc Godard’s journalistic directive that one can — and must — place “everything” in a film, create dystopian versions of New York in which TV and advertising (rightly perceived as synonymous) completely obliterate the divisions between public and private. Both jeremiads correctly and prophetically perceive that advertising not only competes with contemporary American culture; it is contemporary American culture.

Torrenting is something people struggle with these days. Its not the good old days where people gradually learned how to pirate by starting out with napster, then kazaa and then piratebay and always had a brother or friend who could teach them new and better ways. Even then, if it more complicated than just installing a program, downloading a file pressing start to start downloading people would be confused by the tutorial. Usenet adds a step of complexity since simply installing nzbget isn't enough, you have to actually set up shit like your account, server, encryption port and so on. Make any mistake and the software doesn't tell you what you did wrong like a person would, it just pits out some error code you have to look up in the message log to find and you gotta google what that means and then go through the settings to see what you did wrong, assuming you did anything wrong. I had a problem with my encryption certificates a while back, nzbget told me nothing useful and it just kept cancelling the downloads. Had to manually delete the certificates in windows to get the thing to work. No normal user would do that. Ever. They wouldn't even know what a certificate was and if this was their first interaction with it they'd probably assume the software was telling them to do something stupid like delete system32 or something

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178356308
A few still carry the text groups, but hardly any carry binaries. It doesn't really make sense for them to: it uses a shitload of server space, exposes them to legal liability for all of the warez and illegal shit (which, unlike p2p and irc, is actually hosted on their space: an important distinction), and there's not enough demand for it to make up for either of those issues.

I had ISP-supplied Usenet into the DSL era, but not very far into it. We were on Verizon at the time, and they dropped binaries in 2008, and text groups a couple of years later. The only options here are Consolidated Communications (which bought out Fairpoint, which bought Verizon's landlines here), and Comcast. Neither offers Usenet at all.

There are multiple free services which will give you access to the text groups, for whatever that's worth at this point, but if you want binaries in this day and age you're pretty much going to have to pay for a subscription.

posts.com:
I consider Kaneko, Higuchi and Anno the closest the kaiju genre has to auteurs (and Anno pretty much is an auteur). That doesn't make their work best or to be exact best for this particular franchise. For the record I like both GMK and Shin Godzilla.
1)Anno of course has a recognizable style, he brings with him his cast and crew like the plagiarist composer guy. For some time Toho wanted to turn Shin Godzilla into the new default version but it didn't stick. And it could never work. It's clearly a stand alone film, cleverly made but unlike the 1954 movie it's all subtext with no text. I mean that it's very clearly HIS film. Ishiro Honda is still the best Godzilla director in franchise history. Was he a company man? He was a huge filmmaking talent with unrealized potential due to studio politics and he didn't enjoy the same freedom.
2)Kaneko is a Gamera guy, he did great things with Gamera and he pretty much remodelled the entire series the way he wanted. I know his pitch for the Gamera revival was rejected but before we see the anime we won't know how much it owes to his vision of Gamera because I feel like he managed to basically became something like the second original creator of Gamera. But he could never do the same with Godzilla who's a different caliber.
3)Higuchi said some unkind things about Heisei Godzilla and Koichi Kawakita but worked with both Anno and Kaneko on their Godzilla movies. Now he directed Ultraman and I heard a rumor that he's helping with Gamera anime.
Basically their takes on Gamera, Ultraman or (supposedly) Kamen Rider is closer to the core of the characters than their Godzilla movies. So I'm glad that Toho picked that other guy to be the next go to Godzilla director because he's known for putting Godzilla cameos in his movies and he's a fan of the original movies. Doesn't mean his movies will be treading water. I expect them to show something we haven't seen before but they will be much more representative of the heart of the series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally gave this movie a shot and by the end of it, I realised that I just witnessed true kino. Katsumoto's arc stood out to me in particular.

Earlier in the movie, Katsumoto is in the garden and discussing a poem he is writing with Algren.

>The perfect blossom is a rare thing
>You could spend your life looking for one
>And it would not be a wasted life

In the end of the movie, after being mown down by machine gun fire along with the rest of his warriors, Katsumoto gazes at a nearby cherry blossom tree and utters the following words with his final breath.

>Perfect, they are all perfect.

To me, this is the most perfect culmination of a character arc I've seen in film. In his final moments, Katsumoto realises that his search for a single perfect blossom was futile. In the end, all blossoms and everything beautiful in this world is perfect. Don't waste your life looking for singular beauty, find it in all around you. The fault lies in our perception of this world.

>In contrast, the reaction to the film within Japan was mostly positive. There, The Last Samurai opened on 6 December 2003 and was met with high box-office returns and favourable reviews. For example, the film grossed USD111,127,263 in the American market (24.3% of its total revenue), and was ranked 20th in the U.S. box-office movies list. In Japan, the movie grossed USD119,268,595, which surpassed the U.S. figures. This movie was the second most popular movie in Japan in 2003, based on box office sales.1 Critics of the film magazine Kinema Junpō listed The Last Samurai as the fifth best foreign film of 2003, while their readers voted it the second best foreign film of the year, beating out blockbusters such as Chicago [Marshall 2002] and Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers [Jackson 2002] (Kinema Junpō 2004).
>While The Last Samurai elicited a variety of critical and popular responses from admiration to simple indifference, one of the most common reactions of both critics and popular reviewers was one of tears. For example, Ochi Michiō, writing in the film magazine Kinema Junpō, seemed profoundly moved: "What's surprising about this movie is how even one week after watching a preview screening, scenes from the movie keep playing in my mind and continue to be alive. Moreover, my tears start to pour out when I think of them" (Ochi 2003: 35). In addition, many Japanese-language members posted similar reactions on the Yahoo!Japan discussion board. A user, Joker6818 noted that he could not stop crying during the last hour of the movie. Another reviewer, nf7to0268 noted that the audience could not move after the film was over because they were too emotionally drained from crying.

>>178355322
Why would he want to continue being stuck in one of the dullest franchise in the history of movie franchises. Each episode following the boy wizard and his pals from Hogwarts Academy as they fight assorted villains has been indistinguishable from the others. Aside from the gloomy imagery, the series’ only consistency has been its lack of excitement and ineffective use of special effects, all to make magic unmagical, to make action seem inert.

Perhaps the die was cast when Rowling vetoed the idea of Spielberg directing the series; she made sure the series would never be mistaken for a work of art that meant anything to anybody, just ridiculously profitable cross-promotion for her books. The Harry Potter series might be anti-Christian (or not), but it’s certainly the anti-James Bond series in its refusal of wonder, beauty and excitement. No one wants to face that fact. Now, thankfully, they no longer have to.

>a-at least the books were good though
"No!"
The writing is dreadful; the book was terrible. As I read, I noticed that every time a character went for a walk, the author wrote instead that the character "stretched his legs."

I began marking on the back of an envelope every time that phrase was repeated. I stopped only after I had marked the envelope several dozen times. I was incredulous. Rowling's mind is so governed by cliches and dead metaphors that she has no other style of writing. Later I read a lavish, loving review of Harry Potter by the same Stephen King. He wrote something to the effect of, "If these kids are reading Harry Potter at 11 or 12, then when they get older they will go on to read Stephen King." And he was quite right. He was not being ironic. When you read "Harry Potter" you are, in fact, trained to read Stephen King.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dragged Across Concrete was a quite a let down after having watched Brawl in Cell Block Number 99. Though both Brawl in Cell Block 99 and Dragged Across Concrete are long movies, the latter certainly overstays its welcome.

I think it’s because of the fact that Brawl focuses on a single character and his ordeal while Dragged Against Concrete focuses with multiple people and does not manage to give each character proper depth and empathy. Mel Gibson and Vince Vaughn were amazing in their roles, but Tory Kittles and Michael Jai White felt insignificant which came as a surprise cause one of them, Henry, survives the ordeal than either Gibson’s character Ridgeman or Vaugh’s Lurasetti who got the most screen-time and objectively the most attention. (I suppose the director foreshadows their deaths by having Jennifer Carpenter’s mother character Kelly Summer killed so quickly while giving her so much story, even more so than the black characters.) The other two black characters didn’t make me feel much sympathetic for them considering one of them (Michael J White’s character) does not even get much time for audience connection.

Whatever the case, after Vaughn’s character gets killed, the film takes a nosedive in quality only sustained by Mel Gibson and the question if he would come out of the standoff with his life. But then he gets killed later on which felt extremely cheap to me. Earlier Vaughn’s death too was a little unbelievable. I cannot fathom that the two experienced cops would not have got a little bit suspicious when they saw the hostage crawling towards them. The killing of the two most likable protagonists felt subversive in a way cause I expected at least one of them to live. One could argue it fits the theme of “crime does not pay”, but if you are going to kill to your most interesting characters, no amount of kowtowing to THEME is going to save your story.

Overall the experience was pretty forgettable. Brawl is still the better movie.

In the most recent one, the MCs get captured by forest cannibal guys and have to plot an escape... Until it turns out the cannibal guys are really cool dudes who decide to be friends. In 2010, Brendon was tased and arrested by Los Angeles police, who confronted him in response to a call about an intoxicated individual. While participating in the Tree City Comic Con, Brendon was arrested on October 17, 2014 in a Boise, Idaho hotel lobby for misdemeanor charges of malicious injury to property and resisting or obstructing officers. Brendon subsequently made a public apology and stated that the incident was "embarrassing" and the result of drinking alcohol while taking pain medication for a knee problem.[31][32]

>Napoleon by Stanley Kubrick (Waterloo had just flopped so it was seen as too risky)
>Crusade by Paul Verhoeven (The budget was huge and Carolco Pictures was in danger of going bankrupt, so they wanted to spend their remaining money on sure-fire hits like Cutthroat Island and Showgirls)
>The Conquest of Mexico by Werner Herzog (Coppola was the only person who wanted to finance it, but his own film One From the Heart flopped = no cash)
>Genesis by Robert Bresson (L'argent had just flopped)
>Leni Riefenstahl biopic by Steven Soderbergh (too risky creatively)
>Kaleidoscope by Alfred Hitchcock (studio felt the project was too uncommercial and didn't fit the Hitchcock brand)
>Leningrad: The 900 Days by Sergio Leone (funding was secured but Leone died of heart attack)
>Sinatra by Martin Scorsese (Sinatra's family told him to fuck off)
>The Vega Brothers by Quentin Tarantino (lost interest)
>Venus Descending (Marilyn Monroe biopic) by David Lynch (couldn't get funding)

I would never, under any circumstances, get a television or film related tattoo.

You know that's really fucked up that people actually have tattoos like this.

You don't see video game buffs getting Mario tattoos, or trekkies getting tattoos of Admiral Ackbar.

Tattoos are supposed to have meaning.

When I was in the army, I didn't even think about getting a tattoo until near the end of my deployment. I've seen and done some horrible things in my life so when I came back to the states I did a lot of volunteer work which prompted me to get two tattoos of the words "sneed" and "chuck" in chinese on my left and right wrists so that I can remind myself that I am capable of doing both based and redpilled things.

10 years from now I'll look at my wrists and still have profound thoughts of what went through my mind the day I decided to get these tattoos but the idiots who got them because they like movies will only see an outdated, obsolete franchise.
